nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
Site elements
nodes.body: The longer dimension given for each locus below generally corresponds with the direction of the axis of the slope.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (13 m x 5.5 m) is situated 9 m southeast of FS1. FS2 has been reduced to an amorphous rocky dispersion.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS3
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS3 (4.4 m x 6 m) is situated on another prominence (41.478΄ / 27.871΄). Heavily damaged hrough excavation, there is a stone-filled pit (3 m across) in the middle of the structure surrounded by heaps of stones. The lack of soil cover and weathering indicate that this pit was recently excavated.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS4
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS4 (12.4 m x 7.6 m) is situated on the next prominence to the east (41.486΄ / 27.901΄). This specimen has been damaged almost beyond recognition and is now nothing more than a zone of depressions and a stone-filled pit. In the vicinity there is also an excavation (4 m across) filled with loose stones and ringed by piles of earth (41.475΄ / 27.940΄). These piles of earth exhibit no appreciable signs of erosion.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS5
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS5 (25.8 m x 8 m) is a conterminous dispersion consisting of heaps of stones interspersed with pits that exhibit no signs of erosion (41.465΄ / 27.948΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS6
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS6 (17.3 m x 4.5 m) is marked by pits and piles of stones (41.456΄ / 28.015΄). One of the pits is lined with a tiny wall fragment composed of stones, 10 cm to 40 cm in length. This wall appears to have made up one end of the FS6 structure/structures. In close proximity to FS6, a trench (4.7 m x 1.8 m) was recently dug and the excavated stones thrown back into it. This trench was clearly dug to survey subsurface remains. Its creation indicates a good deal of sophistication on the part of the grave robbers.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS7
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS7 (37.2 m x 6 m) is a large dispersion with both old and new excavations (41.474΄ / 28.041΄). Depressions and piles of stones mark FS7.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS8
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS8 (27.6 m x 5.5 m) appears to consist of three discrete quadrate structures (41.462΄ / 28.054΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS9
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS9 (22.5 m x 6.2 m and 7.2 m) consists of two discrete structures (41.385΄ / 28.251΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS10
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS10 (57 m long) is comprised of at least four discrete structural elements (41.374΄ / 28. 262΄). On the north or low end of the dispersion there is a recently dug trench (4 m x 1 m), which has been refilled with stones. There is also a large stony dispersion with no recognizable monuments. Another structural element consists of two highly fragmentary interconnected quadrate enclosures. Finally, there is a large stone depression that was uniformly excavated to a depth of about 1 m.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS11
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS11 (24.8 m x 5 m) is an obscured dispersion that may have consisted of a single structure (41.358΄ / 28.196΄). There are no signs of recent excavation.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS12
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS12 is an ambiguous dispersion (41.342΄ / 28.206΄). Nearby, a pit (5 m x 3.8 m) was recently excavated to a depth of 1.2 m. Another pit in the vicinity (3.3 m x 4.9 m) is 1.5 m deep. These pits do not reveal any traces of subsurface structures.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS13
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS13 (14 m x 5 m) is a rocky dispersion at which excavations have recently taken place (41.318΄ 28.209΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS14
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS14 (28.4 m long) consists of several structures from which stones have been extracted wholesale (41.308΄ / 28.226΄). The largest of these structures (11 m x 15 m) has an eroded depression in the middle of it, the remains of an old excavation.
